THE UNIVERSITY OF CHICAGO
Chicago 37 . Illinois
THE COLLEGE
November 26, 1957
Jfc*. Robert Hudson
Program Manager
Educational Television and Radio Canter
2320 Washtenaw Avenue
Ann Arbor, Michigan
Dear Bobs
By now I am sure that Ray Stanley baa told you that the Committee on
Grants-in-Aid of the N.A.E.B. has approved the proposal for a commissioned
radio series to be produced through the Foreign Policy Association* At
the same time, perhaps he has indicated that our approval proceeded
primarily from a recognition that only this program series, if any, seems
destined to receive support from the Center as an element in the "American
in the Twentieth Century" project for the current year â€” that if the
Foreign Policy Association series were not approved, no Center funds would
go Into radio programming for the current year, beyond the grants already
awarded*
In short, we approved the Foreign Policy aeries with some uneasiness
and it is to make the sources of that uneasiness a matter of record that,
as spokesman for the Committee, 1 am writing you now.
First, let me say that there was initially soma confusion as to the precise
roles to be played by grants and contracts respectively in implementing
the three-year "American in the Twentieth Century" project. Perhaps
improperly, I had assumed at the time our ad hoc committee set up the entire
project that each year the Center and the NlA.E.B., working in complete
collaboration on all phases, would seek to approach our goals as closely
as possible through the grants-in-ald program, relying upon the U3e of
contracts to augment programming in areas where grants proposals wore
inadequate. I now understand that an arbitrary figure of around $40,000
is all that is available under grants-in-aid, regardless of the value of
additional program proposals which would require exceeding that amount.
Accepting this policy (with some bewilderment as to the principle frets
which it derives), we imagined that, following the announcement of grants
awarded, there would be a deliberate, systematic, joint assessment of
areas relatively neglected by the grants series, followed by a sustained,
thoughtful effort to restore balances by defining the kinds of series
needed and establishing appropriate contract arrangements to meet the
needs thus defined* In effect, we assumed that the year would end with
a solid combination of grants and contract programming, the whole of which
would move substantially toward the attainment of our educational objectives.
